Here follows the translation of *Shangqing Hetu Neixuan Jing*, Scroll the Lower:

---

**Corrections and Emendations:**
*#2* The character *dai* (帶, "to wear") is supplied based on context.
*#3* The character *guan* (冠, "crown") was mistakenly written as *fu* (符, "talisman") in the original.
*#4* The character *qun* (裙, "skirt") was mistakenly written as *chen* (晨, "morning") in the original.
*#5* The character *yun* (云, "to say") is supplied from the *Shangqing Hetu Baolu*.
*#6* The character *xie* (懈, "slack") was mistakenly written as *jie* (解, "to untie") in the original.

---

**Incense, Lamps, and Prayer of Thanksgiving (Fourfold)**

Nine lamps are lit: seven with oil, two with incense, arrayed universally toward the north.

A mat is spread south of the lamps, upon which nine trays of jujubes are set. Nine slices of dried meat are placed atop the jujubes, and nine measures of salt are positioned behind the trays. Nine cups of wine are arranged before the trays.

Another mat is laid separately, facing the lamps, where the incense burner is placed. The disciple kneels in reverence, offers incense nine times, and with eyes closed, visualizes the Nine Star Spirits in the heavens above.

Upon completion, the disciple strikes the teeth nine times and rises.

The disciple, a servant of the Three Treasures, [Name], now respectfully invokes:

The Imperial Seat of the Auxiliary Star, Purple Qi Jade Tower, Imperial Lord of the Nine Mornings, August Sovereign, and the August Consort, the High August Left Consort;
The Supreme Lord of the Corrective Star, Jade Tower of the Purple Palace, Imperial Perfected One of the Primordial Dawn, August Sovereign, and the August Consort, the High August Right Consort;
The Youthful Star of Greed and Life, Yang Brightness, Supreme Palace of the Azure City, Jade Tower of the Nine Mornings, August Sovereign, and the August Consort, the Inner Concubine of Escaped Primordial Qi;
The Gate of Greatness in the Ox and Boar, Yin Essence of the Middle Primordial Palace, Five-Colored Jade Tower of the Northern Dawn, August Sovereign, and the August Consort, the Inner Concubine of Transformed Form;
The Star of Emolument in the Tiger and Dog, Perfected One of the True Primordial Palace, Yellow Terrace Jade Tower, Lord of Immortal Splendor, August Sovereign of the Flowering Dawn, and the August Consort, the Mother of the Upper Primordial;
The Star of Literature in the Rabbit and Rooster, Dark Obscurity of the Mystic Tie, Crimson Terrace Jade Tower of the Dark Supreme, Flying Canopy of the Mystic Dawn, August Sovereign, and the August Consort, the Inner Concubine of the Originating Primordial;
The Star of Integrity in the Dragon and Monkey, Cinnabar Primordial Ridge, White Terrace of the Golden Jade Tower, Golden Chief of the Seven Mornings, August Sovereign, and the August Consort, the Eldest Maiden of the Dipper;
The Star of Valor in the Serpent and Ram, Northern Buttress of the Dark Record, Dark Terrace Jade Tower, Northern Asterism of Flying Splendor, August Sovereign, and the August Consort, the Middle Maiden of the Dipper;
The Star of Ruin in the Horse and Life, Celestial Pass of the Heavenly Assembly, Nine-Tiered Jade Tower, Sovereign of the Total Spirit of the Nine Primordials, August Sovereign of the Northern Canopy, and the August Consort, the Youngest Maiden of the Dipper.

Respectfully invoked are the Seven Numinous Great Spirits, the Nine Essences of the Imperial Dawn, the Four August Ones who bend their gaze in condescension. May they, in compassion for this sincere heart, deign to descend in cloud-borne chariots, their sacred radiance stirring.

Together with the Lord of Central Harmony, the Lord of Myriad Blessings, the Lord of Extended Longevity, the Lord of Cherished Life, the Lord of Bright Calculation, the Lord of Preserved Records, the Lord of Fixed Destiny, the Lord of Rewarding Goodness, the Lord of Answering Wishes, the Divine Lads and Jade Maidens, the Direct Talismans and Direct Officers, the Perfected Generals and Cavalry Attendants, and all their official retinues—may they all descend upon this open altar within [Name]’s village, observe the earnest devotion of this supplicant, and partake of this humble offering.

This servant, [Name], shares a bond of Dao and righteousness with [Name], enduring and karmically linked, their affection akin to flesh and blood, their hearts united in devotion.

[Name] surrenders life to the Nine August High Ones, the Seven Sacred Great Spirits, the Supreme Perfection of the Great Dao, and the Venerable Lords.

This servant, [Name], with awe and trepidation, bows twice in reverence.

Further, the wine is poured into cups, lifted three times, and offered thrice, completing nine offerings of wine, thus fulfilling the ninefold libation.

The disciple, a servant of the Three Treasures, [Name], now addresses the Seven Numinous Great Spirits, the Nine Essences of the Imperial Dawn, the Illustrious High Ones, the Lords of Virtue and Power, and all the Perfected Spirits:

Today, with utmost sincerity, [Name], of [State], [Commandery], [County], [Village], [Residence], presents this written petition, humbly reciting as follows.

This servant prostrates in hope that all the divine luminaries will reflect upon these words and, together with the modest offerings now set forth, accept the life-bound silken banners of [X] feet, presented before the Jade Mechanism of the August Sovereign and Consort corresponding to [Name]’s destiny. May they redeem and ransom [Name]’s fated expiration, beseeching the grace of renewal.

May the August Sovereigns and Consorts, moved by this sincere plea, partake of these humble offerings and bear witness to this covenant.

It is humbly prayed that the assembled spirits will exhort the August Sovereigns and Consorts to bestow compassionate grace, respond to this entreaty, and grant [Name] perpetual freedom from calamitous illness, sparing them from the sorrow of mortal affliction, delivering them from unforeseen misfortune. May all disasters dissolve, every endeavor align with the heart’s desire, and every aspiration be fulfilled. May this sincere devotion be conveyed through this servant.

This servant, though unworthy, has presumptuously joined the true teaching, aspiring to propagate the mysterious wind, to succor all beings, placing others before self, and never daring to slacken.

Now, unable to contain this earnest and reverent devotion, this servant ventures to present this humble plea.

Yet human life is ever in motion, truly beset by many [lacuna]. Through ignorance and darkness, one strays from the true path, leading to delusion and loss of the correct Way.

Upon reflection, principle resides in the realm of existence, and one cannot be without mind. What the mind pursues must be to dispel darkness and seek illumination. Illumination must be polished and brought forth by the sacred and numinous. When the mysterious reward is granted, the sacred permits gratitude; when the divine permits mercy, mercy arises from sincerity. Gratitude is tied to the purification of the heart. When the heart is exhausted, repentance for boundless transgressions begins; when sincerity is complete, the rites of offering must be respectfully presented. When the rites are perfected, divine protection will surely arrive; when transgressions are absolved, virtuous wishes will surely harmonize.

In accordance with this principle, this servant dares to lay bare this sincere heart.

The ancient sages offered sacrifices to Heaven in the wilds and to Earth in the open, gazing in reverence toward mountains and rivers. The former sages bequeathed these rites in their external counsels, and later sages upheld them to perfect virtue. As for invoking the Five Elders to pray to the Great One, summoning the Eight Numinous Ones to attract the Six Spirits—these mysteries were already expounded in the inner teachings, and the luminous decrees followed to propagate the Dao. Ranks and positions are ordered, their wonder lying in the absence of deviation.

Thus, in offering and cultivation, one acts according to intent, presenting gifts in due season. The noble do not disdain abundance, nor do the humble restrict themselves to frugality.

Azure silk adorned with *lin* and *feng* birds, jade-like wine and nectar of jasper—these are the provisions of those who ascend to the heights, not the means of the lowly and impoverished.

As for the offerings of swans and egrets to the Supreme Emperor, or the tender *ping* and *zao* herbs presented to the august deities—these are not rites this humble servant may perform, nor are they the ultimate expression of this sincere devotion.

chunks.original_text: 某今刷贫依法，供办酒脯盐豉等味，然灯照曜，以秉发皇灵，烧香腾启，以仰期感应。 是以濯浣身神，投命玄极，竭其归仰之丹心，不愿轻微之菲陋。 伏愿明灵大圣，至真尊神，特赐愍佑，副其翘勤。 臣恐谴重功微，方罹殃考，性命难保，子孙难得，所向乖心。 今仰凭玄真善成无弃，谨自整洁，洗濯身心，为某首舍众衅。 某从无始世界以来，经劫无数，或为男女人，至于今生转轮未息。 或尝运性鄙蔽，立志猖狂，不信大道，不敬神明，为子不孝，为父不慈，为君不道，为臣不忠，为兄不友，为弟不和，为长不慎，为幼不恭，为师主不敬，为弟子不谨，为朋俦不义，为宾友不诚，为姑不笃，为妇不虔，为母不爱，为姨不敦，为舅氏不穆，为伯叔不仁，为娣姒不顺，为妾媵不谦，为夫妻不睦，为嫡庶不平，为内不静，为外不明，为上不轨，为下不清，为贱不逊，为贵不廉，为男不洁，为女不贞，不达义方，不了妙趣，芒昧玄宗，留连世务，尘路思着，俗海忘超，五情六欲，触荡精神，三毒七积，挠乱心志，业行不专，取舍非一，进退无恒，异端盈臆，道风既亏，世范又缺，身与年衰，衅随日结，动不顾利，静不修戒，深福大善，永不议作，巨祸洪恶，日夜竞为。 或有急之日暂存道，小宽之辰辄忘真，返逆无状，纵横肆心。 或凭威乘势，恃宠强梁，或毁道败德，杀害君亲，破坏经图，攻伐师尊，诛伤同气，杀戮友朋，酷虐万类，轻誷百灵。 或发泄冢墓，开他棺椁，刑尸罚鬼，惊骸动神，欺灭侪党，痛感天人。 或斩斫神主，焚烧社庙，阴怀谋逆，阳论顺命，嫉妬胜己，谗谤忠贞，纵逞楚毒，抑绝贤明，捐交弃好，苦克邦乡，谮善长恶，讪诮才良，悭贪益己，不愿施人，割夺四辈，唯润一身，食啖百姓，受取万端，得无厌足，侵略人神。 或藉贵怙富，凌贱孤贫，或略人所爱，离隔六亲，分绝骨肉，断遏四邻。 或蒸通九属，淫犯万殊，恣溢失度，謟忌无拘，强相咒咀，妄加善人，叫唤骂詈，牵引鬼神，指斥日月，告诉星辰。 或劝人作恶，不教童蒙，暗任纵横，观人成败。 或好色耽酒，丽饰自玩，胸心颠倒，粗恶险暴，歌哭无常，举止不觉，掊击东西，翻覆南北。 或手肆凶逆，或侠他行虐，或妄触人神，叨忤清净，慠突明灵，评论经教，诽诮正法，违负信约，欺诱娇诈，妖媚谀佞。 或嗔恚忿恨，残克自高，唝嗃并势，贪婪日结。 或戏谑胜负，冈蔑尪微，诳惑朝野，嘲调闺帏。 或外伪刚直，内怀曲刃，干知是非，以退为进，强占星宿，卜相自衒，妄期祸福，表里无信，面誉背毁，巧言令色，误脱家邦，破乱宗国。 或不敬明德，不纳忠言，阴嫉高胜，潜害英能。 或假托神鬼，诈称天灵，窃予妄言，妖惑百姓，扇动天地，骇怛神明。 或断截人路，逼迮母子，闭塞人善良，抑绝人休美。 或积药思人病，蓄棺愿老死，訾人学方，自誉己业，虚造生空，妄作一法，不达权化，谬怀疑贰。 或因公行私，迷误后世，好乐臭腥，忌要芳净。 或驰骋田猎，呵骂风雨，奸盗劫贼，刺射天地。 阴罪阴过，阳罪阳过，死罪死过，幽显遍知，反理违经，犯律破戒，上负三光四时五行，下忤万象九宫六甲，中触里域神祇，冢宅精灵，先亡魂爽，井灶门庭，出入户路，履历庄衢，经涉失祀，所在违和，处处犯禁，种种成□。

This humble servant, though impoverished, has prepared according to the law offerings of wine, dried meats, salt, and fermented beans, and kindled lamps to illuminate and invoke the radiant numen. I burn incense to ascend my prayers, hoping for a response. Thus, I purify my body and spirit, entrusting my fate to the Mysterious Ultimate, exhausting the cinnabar sincerity of my devotion, undeterred by the meagerness of these humble offerings.

I humbly beseech the luminous spirits, the great sages, the perfected and august deities to bestow their compassionate protection and fulfill my earnest supplications. This servant fears that my transgressions are grave while my merits are slight, that I may soon suffer calamity and affliction, my life imperiled, my descendants lost, and all my aspirations thwarted.

Now, relying on the Mysterious Perfection to bring good to completion without abandonment, I have meticulously cleansed myself, washing body and heart, offering myself first to atone for all transgressions.

From the beginningless world through countless kalpas, I have transmigrated without cease—now as man, now as woman—until this present life. At times, my nature has been base and obscured, my resolve reckless and wild. I have failed to believe in the Great Dao, failed to revere the divine. As a child, I was unfilial; as a father, unkind. As a ruler, I lacked the Way; as a minister, loyalty. As an elder brother, I was unfraternal; as a younger, discordant. As an elder, I was careless; as a youth, irreverent. As a teacher, I was disrespected; as a disciple, negligent. As a friend, I was unrighteous; as a companion, insincere. As an aunt, I was unkind; as a wife, irreverent. As a mother, unloving; as a sister-in-law, undutiful. To my maternal uncles, I was disrespectful; to my paternal uncles, unbenevolent. To my sisters-in-law, I was unyielding; to my concubines, arrogant. With my spouse, I was disharmonious; among my children, unjust. Within, I was restless; without, unclear. To my superiors, I was unruly; to my subordinates, impure. To the lowly, I was insolent; to the noble, corrupt. As a man, I was unclean; as a woman, unchaste. I failed to grasp the principles of righteousness, failed to comprehend the subtle wonders. I was ignorant of the Mysterious Origin, entangled in worldly affairs, my thoughts mired in the dusty paths, forgetting to transcend the sea of俗. The five passions and six desires disturbed my spirit; the three poisons and seven accumulations confounded my heart. My deeds lacked focus, my choices were inconsistent, my conduct wavering. Heretical thoughts filled my mind, the Dao’s influence waned, and the world’s standards crumbled. My body and years declined, my transgressions accumulated daily. In action, I disregarded benefit; in stillness, I neglected precepts. Profound blessings and great goodness I never considered; vast calamities and grievous evils I committed day and night.

At times, in urgency, I briefly upheld the Dao, only to forget the True when circumstances eased. I acted perversely, indulging my will without restraint. Sometimes, I relied on power and influence, wielding authority with arrogance. At others, I undermined the Dao and corrupted virtue, harming rulers and kin, destroying scriptures and diagrams, assaulting my teachers, injuring my peers, slaughtering friends, oppressing all beings, and scorning the spirits. I desecrated tombs, opened coffins, mutilated corpses, punished ghosts, disturbed bones, and startled the dead, causing pain to my companions and distress to heaven and humanity. I hacked at spirit tablets, burned shrines, secretly plotted rebellion while outwardly feigning obedience. I envied those superior to me, slandered the loyal and steadfast, unleashed cruelty, suppressed the worthy, abandoned friends, tormented my homeland, slandered the good, mocked the talented, hoarded for myself, and refused to give to others. I seized from all quarters to enrich myself alone, devoured the people’s livelihood, and extorted in myriad ways, never satisfied, encroaching upon gods and men.

At times, I exploited my status or wealth to bully the lowly and orphaned, or seized what others loved, severing the six relations, cutting off kin, and isolating neighbors. I violated the nine degrees of kinship, indulged in myriad perversions, lost all restraint, schemed without scruple, cursed others, and falsely accused the virtuous. I railed and reviled, invoking ghosts and spirits, pointing at the sun and moon, and lodging complaints with the stars. I encouraged others to do evil, failed to teach the young, acted recklessly in darkness, and watched others succeed or fail. I indulged in lust and wine, adorned myself for vanity, my heart and mind inverted, my nature coarse, cruel, and violent. My laughter and tears were erratic, my conduct unchecked. I struck out in all directions, overturning all before me. At times, my hands committed violence; at others, I abetted others’ cruelty. I recklessly offended gods and men, disturbed the pure and tranquil, and arrogantly defied the luminous spirits. I criticized the scriptures and teachings, slandered the true Dharma, betrayed promises, deceived with cunning, flattered with seductive words, and fawned with insincerity. I was wrathful and resentful, cruel and domineering, arrogant and overbearing, my greed growing daily. I gambled for victory, mocked the weak, deceived the court and the countryside, and ridiculed the inner chambers. Outwardly, I feigned integrity while inwardly harboring treachery, manipulating right and wrong to advance my ends. I forcibly claimed the stars, boasted of my divination, falsely predicted fortune and misfortune, and acted duplicitously, praising to the face and slandering behind the back. With honeyed words and false smiles, I misled my homeland and disrupted my ancestral state. I disrespected the virtuous, rejected loyal advice, secretly envied the excellent, and covertly harmed the capable. I impersonated gods and spirits, falsely invoked the celestial, spoke deceitfully, and bewitched the people, stirring heaven and earth, startling the divine. I blocked roads, separated mother and child, obstructed the good, and suppressed the virtuous. I stockpiled medicines to wish illness upon others, hoarded coffins to await their deaths, disparaged others’ learning while praising my own, fabricated empty doctrines, and misapplied a single method, failing to grasp the subtleties of transformation and harboring doubts. I used public office for private gain, misled later generations, delighted in foulness, and shunned purity. I galloped in the hunt, cursed the wind and rain, committed robbery and theft, and shot arrows at heaven and earth.

My transgressions—whether hidden or manifest, mortal or spiritual—are known throughout the unseen and visible realms. I have defied reason, violated the scriptures, broken the laws and precepts. Above, I have betrayed the Three Luminaries, the Four Seasons, and the Five Phases; below, I have offended the myriad phenomena, the Nine Palaces, and the Six Jia. In between, I have disturbed the local deities, the spirits of tombs and dwellings, the souls of my ancestors, the hearth and gate gods, the spirits of roads and thresholds, and all the deities of the paths I have trodden. Wherever I have gone, I have neglected sacrifices, violated harmony, and broken prohibitions, accumulating transgressions in every place.

chunks.original_text: 或知而故为，或谬误不觉，或被迫从人，或身心自构，或忍而无悔，或悔而未谢，或谢而又犯，未能长革，或久谪衅探，未能永悛，或日积月深，无限无量，不可具陈，或中表相牵，内外相染，男女大小，一切眷属，后世今生，俱有罪过，更相延误。 或同谋共作，或尊上使为，或悬相要拟，傍生罪根，因缘在彼，自不觉知。 或操不坚，被试不过，神鬼遘怨，师徒连祸，先仇宿对，方未解释，后晚结咎，稍复滋繁。 或尝为奴婢，役使胡夷蛮貊，戎狄氏羌，鱼乌虫兽，魔邪精魅，穷粗极丑，更相食啖，雠报未终。 所陈条目，略而未尽，回环历劫，不可忆知，犯与不犯，不自分别，各在两宫七十四部，事简三元百二十曹，结咎既深，考在不测，将虑一日一奄同尘壤，小事云处世规图，惧不如心。 某今投命九皇大圣尊神，仰凭至德，特乞降佑，赐垂慈恩，令五岳使者，即颁下所由，随源料理，罪文咎结，一切解除，以宥其谪，断绝恶根，积衅累愆，悉蒙洗荡，辅导信心，开通善路，正气流滋，贵神保护。 某已往之衅都洗，即今之愆悉除，当来之尤不生，从善之志日进，上学之愿无退，修经习戒，以今为始。 三界五帝六甲九宫玄洲灵洞主土真官，无量仙圣一切善神，赐纳臣言，同记今请，矜某首洗之丹心，愍某自新之慊志，采臣劝善之誓言，副臣归仰之丹诚，令都天监司过君，延生之局增福之司，咸共削某黑簿，注名青文，令众灾度脱，寿命延长，长保福庆，合门兴隆，凶妖消散，善愿咸从，梦想真正，冢宅安宁，止殃灭注，内外同休，以显玄神明信之验，以酬某元元之心。 随意续言，每在省约。 某又一上酒毕，各三过止。 臣某重启九皇尊神，七圣明灵，一切正神，臣以刍陋，生长流俗，不闲妙法，恐所施失仪，言辞饕餮，触忤威灵，进止违典，举事□深，惧不能相济，还婴咎责。 特愿明灵曲垂照愍，哀矜不及，奖成善心，不加谴罚，宿衅蒙原，臣所愿皆得谐心。 欲有愿乐，随意言之。 某荷恩之日，并依科重献诚礼，一如今夕。 某伏愿明灵大神，一切真官，同垂慈恩，共赐开导，与善相因，神灵奖悦，所启所愿，即蒙御闻，今夜所请，必遂如心，则仰荷明神更造之恩。 今乞洪泽浃润某身，请以余杯，赐某饮进，令神炁降洽，善愿克谐。 取此人命所属酒一杯，与饮之。 臣上启九皇大神，明灵高尊，道德诸君，一切善神，向有某甲为某事云，臣与道义，因缘冒昧干请，仰屈威灵临鉴已久，不敢稽淹神驾，愿各还本官，安神复御，垂神流恩，以景福祚延长，约勅所在土地真官，宅舍善吏，堂宇僚局，明各荣卫某身及臣，使积罪永除，福名更始，令所请如启，所愿必遂，不孤至向，须后有请，仰希重降。 臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首再拜。 送神，依次拜送。 拜送神，亦可都再拜而已，仍伏叩头，乞升车之恩，必副元元之情，欲有所言，随人意密道毕，起复炉。 若度事后即醮，未可复炉，仍设醮，醮竟，复炉也。 醮毕，取第一杯酒少许灌地，不必令尽。 若欲以治病，病人所属星杯，可取与饮之。 无病厄者，悉出外，赋作礼敬进之。 勿及异人疑怪，彼此得罪。 其所识，悉笃信无嫌者，皆得分之。 若度事之后，别时设醮，或自为、为人乞愿请恩，并存神竟，扣齿发炉。

Should some transgressions be committed knowingly, others by unwitting error; some under coercion by others, others self-wrought in body and mind; some endured without remorse, others repented yet unatoned; some atoned yet repeated, never fully reformed; some long exiled by fate’s probing, never truly reformed; some accrued day by day, month by month, boundless and immeasurable, beyond full recounting—

Or entangled by kinship, tainted by inner and outer influences, where men and women, young and old, all kinfolk, in past lives and this, share in guilt, each leading the other astray. Some conspire together, some act at the behest of superiors, some bound by mutual pledges, sowing the roots of sin in others, their karmic ties unseen.

Or wavering in resolve, failing trials, incurring the wrath of gods and ghosts, entangling masters and disciples in misfortune; old grudges unresolved, new faults compounding, growing ever more intricate.

Or once enslaved, made to serve Hu, Yi, Man, Mo, Rong, Di, Qiang, fish and birds, insects and beasts, demons and malevolent spirits—creatures coarse and vile—devouring one another in endless cycles of vengeance unfulfilled.

The offenses listed here are but a fraction, unending through kalpas, beyond memory or reckoning. Whether committed or not, one cannot discern, for all are recorded in the Two Palaces and the Seventy-Four Bureaus, their cases reviewed by the Three Primes and the One Hundred Twenty Offices. With guilt so deep, judgment lies beyond measure—fearing that in a single day, one may return to dust, and even minor matters may fall short of worldly expectations.

Now, I entrust my fate to the Nine August Great Sage Honored Deities, beseeching their supreme virtue to bestow protection. May they grant compassion, commanding the Envoys of the Five Peaks to dispatch their agents, tracing the roots of my transgressions to dissolve all records of guilt and entanglements, pardoning my exile, severing the roots of evil, washing away accumulated offenses and burdens. May they guide my faithful heart, open the path of goodness, let the flow of upright qi flourish, and grant the protection of noble spirits.

May all my past offenses be cleansed, present faults erased, and future wrongs never arise. May my resolve to do good grow daily, my aspiration for higher learning never wane, and my study of scriptures and precepts begin anew from this day.

May the Lords of the Three Realms, the Five Emperors, the Six Jia, the Nine Palaces, and the Mystic Continent’s Cavern Masters, along with the countless immortals and sages, all benevolent spirits, heed my plea. Take note of my earnest repentance, pity my resolve to renew myself, accept my vow to encourage goodness, and fulfill my sincere devotion. May the Overseers of the All-Heaven Judgment Bureau, the Bureaus of Longevity and Fortune, together erase my name from the Black Register and inscribe it in the Azure Script. May all disasters be averted, my lifespan extended, and lasting blessings secured for my family’s prosperity. May malevolent omens dissipate, all good wishes be granted, dreams be true, tombs and dwellings peaceful, calamities cease, and inner and outer realms harmonize—revealing the efficacy of the mysterious and divine, repaying my deepest hopes.

Now, as I continue my words, let them remain measured and concise.

I offer wine once more, thrice in all.

I, [Name], humbly address the Nine August Honored Deities, the Seven Illustrious Spirits, and all the righteous gods. Born of humble origins in the mundane world, untrained in subtle Dharma, I fear my offerings may lack propriety, my words coarse and excessive, offending your majesty, my conduct violating ritual, my actions deeply flawed. I dread failure and the return of blame.

May your luminous spirits graciously look upon me with compassion, pitying my inadequacies, fostering my good intentions, and sparing me from punishment. May past offenses be pardoned, and all my wishes fulfilled.

Should I have further desires, I shall express them as I will.

From the day I receive your grace, I shall offer sincere rites as prescribed, just as tonight.

I prostrate myself, praying that the luminous great spirits and all true officials bestow their compassion, guiding me toward goodness, delighting in my devotion. May all my petitions and wishes be heard, and tonight’s pleas granted as my heart desires—so that I may forever bear the boundless grace of your renewal.

Now, I beseech your vast blessings to saturate my being. I offer the remaining wine, asking you to drink and let the divine qi descend upon me, fulfilling my good intentions.

I take this cup of wine, belonging to the star governing my life, and drink it.

I, [Name], address the Nine August Great Deities, the Illustrious and Exalted, the Lords of Dao and Virtue, and all benevolent spirits. Regarding [Name]’s matter of [specific request], bound by Dao and righteousness, I have presumptuously entreated your majesty to witness my plea for some time. I dare not delay your divine presence further. May you return to your respective offices, settle your spirits, and resume your thrones, bestowing divine grace to extend blessings and longevity. I command the local earth deities, the household spirits, the officials of halls and chambers, to safeguard [Name] and myself, permanently erasing our accumulated sins and renewing our fortunes. May all requests be granted as stated, all wishes fulfilled, and my devotion never in vain. Should future petitions arise, I humbly await your return.

I, [Name], in awe and reverence, bow twice in prostration.

Send off the deities in due order, bowing as you do.

When sending off the deities, one may simply bow twice, then kneel and kowtow, beseeching the grace of their ascent. If further words are needed, speak them privately as you wish, then rise and close the incense burner.

If the ritual follows immediately after the matter’s resolution, do not close the incense burner; instead, proceed with the offering. After the offering concludes, then close the incense burner.

Upon completing the offering, pour a small amount of the first cup of wine onto the ground—no need to empty it.

If treating an illness, take the cup belonging to the patient’s governing star and let them drink.

If no illness or misfortune afflicts others, have them all step outside, perform rites of respect, and present the wine.

Do not involve strangers or arouse suspicion, lest both parties incur offense.

Only those known and trusted without doubt may partake.

If, after the matter’s resolution, a separate offering is held at another time—whether for oneself or another, to seek blessings or grace—once the invocation of spirits concludes, strike the teeth and open the incense burner.

chunks.original_text: 若入坛堂，漱咒如法。 凡学士功轻，未能得道传授灵文，更相开度，建德立功，良时吉日祈请玄恩，同先谢过。 生由九炁，成由九天，学由九业，品极九阶，仙真及圣，各有经法，习之未周，不能免咎，有所云为皆悔罪为端，然后恩佑不求自至。 求福以着入微，故先阳明至辅弼，除罪以微至着，故先辅弼以至阳明。 谢文贵赋，前辞消息，受事请恩，依源廷诏，唯首谢正同，迎送不异。 危急修之，可略谢耳。 观星要法 凡受九皇讳后，良夜请天，恒谛观北斗，存识次第内外姓名，思见神降，与己语言。 次觅辅弼，令得见形，精心注仰，久自睹之。 观星唯密，勿令他知，或有问者，余言答之，不得泄露，通其所视，见与不见，皆莫出言，心之与眼相知而已。 观星之时，洗净身炁，垢则沐浴，秽则易衣。 衣服芬馨，内外净洁，烧香所止，存启玄灵，熟看经图，分明忆识，然后出视，勿忽遑高言，又勿多人，同志可三耳。 同志才非，亦勿与共，各处为之，勿相访问。 有事劳倦，醉饱交接，调和未平，皆勿仰观。 又醮祭谢过，礼拜乞恩，积久无征，由於不观。 观虽未见，诚至心感，稍稍懃之，永不懈退，必获了然，见则神降，醮礼即验，兼济无穷。 不能精心习学仰观，魔来坏人，凶怪相动，醮礼空费，劳而罪臻。 有志之人，明相警戒。 九星所摄，各有分野，占候吉凶，往来出入住止，求须营理，道俗皆当精察，以定所宜，可否去就，回败为成，寻贤得贤，访圣得圣，所作利贞，长保元吉矣。 事九皇王君，昼夜行卧坐息，饮食交接云为，恒思见之，俯仰屈伸，念念不忘，九年神降，受长生之诀也。 天中心号北辰，有五星。 第一大星，名天枢，为母，第二天子，第三太子，第四次子，第五名北极，天一所生。 太一所居止在紫宫。 紫宫东八星，西七星，列为藩臣，中央紫微宫，太一常舍，为五官二十八宿，金木水火土属五星，五星五属，北斗属太一，太一为极，位居最尊。 北斗九星宿卫太一，占其吉凶善恶，诀如左。 北极空洞正天之中，北极在此空之南，此空之在北极之北，故曰北辰，众星共之。 第一为魁头，名天枢天，一名正星，字贪狼，位御史中丞，为天为日，主阳德，天子象，以壁室奎娄为徐州，主五子，岁星。 第二地璇，一名法星，字巨门，位大司马，为地为月，主阴刑，女主象，以胃昴毕赀为梁州，后分为益州，主五亥，太皇星。 第三人玑，一名命星，字禄存，位少府，为人道，主祸，以参井鬼柳为冀州，主五戌，荧惑星。 第四物权，一名伐星，字文曲，位司徒光禄，为四时，主伐无道，以七星张翼轸为荆州，主五卯，辰星。 第五玉衡，一名杀星，字廉贞，位大鸿胪，为杀有罪，以角亢氏房为兖州，主五辰，镇星。 第六闿阳，一名危星，字武曲，位廷尉，为食谷，以心尾箕为扬州，主五色，岁星。 第七瑶光，一名部星，字破军，位执金吾，为兵，以斗牛女虚危为豫州，主五午，白星。 第八为外辅，在北斗第六星下，相去一寸许。 第九为内辅，一星在北斗第三星上，不可得见，见之长成神圣也。 占八星，审同里，其位有灾，其境有害，皆宜避之。 小则厌禳，修功德，立礼醮来恩，密而勿言，祸消福集矣。

If entering the altar hall, rinse and recite the incantation according to the proper method.

For those whose cultivation is shallow and who have not yet received the transmission of sacred texts from the Dao, they may mutually initiate and guide one another, establishing virtue and merit. On an auspicious day and at a propitious hour, they may pray for profound grace, first giving thanks for past transgressions.

Life arises from the nine *qi*, completion from the nine heavens, learning from the nine disciplines, and rank culminates in the nine grades. Immortals and sages each possess their own scriptures and methods; if one’s practice is incomplete, one cannot avoid fault. Whatever one undertakes must begin with repentance for sins, and only then will grace and protection arrive unbidden.

To seek blessings, proceed from the subtle to the manifest—thus, begin with *Yangming* and proceed to the *Fubi*. To remove transgressions, proceed from the manifest to the subtle—thus, begin with the *Fubi* and proceed to *Yangming*. The efficacy of repentance lies in its sincerity; the opening words must convey the ebb and flow of intention. When receiving tasks or seeking grace, follow the original decree from the celestial court. The primary repentance should be uniform, and the rites of welcoming and sending off should not differ. In times of peril, the repentance may be abbreviated.

**Essential Methods for Observing the Stars**

After receiving the taboo names of the Nine August Ones, on a clear night, invoke the heavens and diligently observe the Northern Dipper. Visualize and memorize the order of the stars, their inner and outer names, and imagine the descent of the deities, speaking with them in your mind. Next, seek the *Fubi* stars, striving to perceive their forms. With focused concentration and reverent gaze, you will eventually behold them.

The observation of stars must be kept secret; do not let others know. If questioned, respond vaguely. Do not reveal anything, whether you see them or not—utter no word of it. Only the heart and eyes may share this knowledge.

When observing the stars, purify your body and *qi*. If defiled, bathe; if impure, change your garments. Clothing should be fragrant, and both inner and outer aspects immaculate. Where incense burns, invoke the mysterious spirits. Study the scriptures and charts carefully, memorizing them clearly before gazing outward. Do not speak carelessly or boastfully, and do not gather many people—only two or three like-minded companions. If a companion lacks the proper resolve, do not observe with them; each should practice separately, without visiting or inquiring of one another.

If fatigued, intoxicated, sated, or after conjugal union, or if one’s *qi* is unsettled, do not look upon the stars. Furthermore, if offerings, repentance rites, prostrations, or prayers for grace yield no signs over time, it is due to a lack of observation. Though one may not yet see the stars, sincerity and devotion will gradually bring results. Persist without slackening, and you will surely attain clarity. Once seen, the deities will descend, the offerings will prove efficacious, and boundless aid will follow. If one does not diligently study and observe the stars with a focused mind, demonic forces may assail them, inauspicious omens arise, and offerings will be wasted, laboring in vain while incurring transgressions. Those of resolute intent should take heed and be warned.

The nine stars govern distinct regions, and their configurations foretell fortune or misfortune in travel, residence, and all undertakings. Both Daoists and laypeople must examine them carefully to determine what is fitting, whether to proceed or withdraw, to transform failure into success, to seek the worthy and find them, to consult the sagely and encounter them. All actions will be upright and enduringly auspicious.

In serving the Nine August Sovereign Lords, whether by day or night, in movement or stillness, eating, drinking, or conjugal union, constantly visualize their presence. In every posture and gesture, never forget them. After nine years, the deities will descend, and you will receive the secret of eternal life.

The center of the heavens is called the Northern Asterism, comprising five stars. The first, the great star, is named *Tianshu* (Celestial Pivot), the Mother. The second is the Son, the third the Crown Prince, the fourth the Second Son, and the fifth is called *Beiji* (Northern Pole), born of *Tianyi* (Heavenly One). *Taiyi* (Great One) resides in the Purple Palace. To the east of the Purple Palace are eight stars, to the west seven, arrayed as vassal ministers. At its center lies the Purple Tenuity Palace, where *Taiyi* dwells, governing the five officials and the twenty-eight constellations. The five planets—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—correspond to the five stars, and the five stars correspond to the five phases. The Northern Dipper belongs to *Taiyi*, and *Taiyi* is the Pole, occupying the most exalted position.

The nine stars of the Northern Dipper guard *Taiyi*, and their auspices—whether fortunate or ill—are determined as follows:

The Northern Pole is the hollow center of the heavens. The Northern Pole lies south of this hollow, and the hollow lies north of the Northern Pole, hence it is called the Northern Asterism, around which all stars revolve.

1. The first star is the head of the Dipper, named *Tianshu* (Celestial Pivot), also called the *Zhengxing* (Principal Star) or *Tanlang* (Greedy Wolf). It holds the position of Imperial Censor and represents the heavens and the sun, governing yang virtue and symbolizing the Son of Heaven. Its domain is *Xuzhou*, corresponding to the constellations *Bishu*, *Kui*, and *Lou*, and it governs the fifth earthly branch (*chen*), associated with Jupiter.

2. The second star is *Dixuan* (Celestial Rotator), also called the *Faxing* (Law Star) or *Jumen* (Great Gate). It holds the position of Grand Marshal and represents the earth and the moon, governing yin punishment and symbolizing the Queen. Its domain is *Liangzhou* (later divided into *Yizhou*), corresponding to the constellations *Wei*, *Mao*, and *Bi*, and it governs the fifth branch (*hai*), associated with the Grand White Star.

3. The third star is *Renji* (Human Axis), also called the *Mingxing* (Life Star) or *Lucun* (Salary Storage). It holds the position of Chamberlain for the Palace Revenues and represents humanity, governing calamities. Its domain is *Jizhou*, corresponding to the constellations *Shen*, *Jing*, *Gui*, and *Liu*, and it governs the fifth branch (*xu*), associated with Mars.

4. The fourth star is *Wuquan* (Material Balance), also called the *Faxing* (Punishment Star) or *Wenqu* (Literary Curvature). It holds the position of Minister of Education and Grand Master of Ceremonies and represents the four seasons, governing the punishment of the unrighteous. Its domain is *Jingzhou*, corresponding to the constellations *Qixing*, *Zhang*, *Yi*, and *Zhen*, and it governs the fifth branch (*mao*), associated with Mercury.

5. The fifth star is *Yuheng* (Jade Balance), also called the *Shaxing* (Execution Star) or *Lianzhen* (Upright Integrity). It holds the position of Grand Herald and governs the execution of the guilty. Its domain is *Yanzhou*, corresponding to the constellations *Jiao*, *Kang*, *Di*, and *Fang*, and it governs the fifth branch (*chen*), associated with Saturn.

6. The sixth star is *Kaiyang* (Opening Yang), also called the *Weixing* (Danger Star) or *Wuqu* (Martial Curvature). It holds the position of Commandant of Justice and governs the sustenance of grain. Its domain is *Yangzhou*, corresponding to the constellations *Xin*, *Wei*, and *Ji*, and it governs the five colors, associated with Jupiter.

7. The seventh star is *Yaoguang* (Luminous Jade), also called the *Buxing* (Department Star) or *Pojun* (Breaking Army). It holds the position of Commandant of the Capital and governs warfare. Its domain is *Yuzhou*, corresponding to the constellations *Dou*, *Niu*, *Nü*, *Xu*, and *Wei*, and it governs the fifth branch (*wu*), associated with Venus.

8. The eighth star is the *Waifu* (Outer Assistant), located below the sixth star of the Northern Dipper, approximately one *cun* away.

9. The ninth star is the *Neifu* (Inner Assistant), a single star above the third star of the Northern Dipper, which is not ordinarily visible. If seen, it portends the attainment of divine sagehood.

When divining the eight stars, examine their positions within their domains. If a star’s position portends disaster or its domain suffers harm, one should avoid it. For minor afflictions, perform exorcisms, cultivate merit, establish rites, and offer repentance to invoke grace—all in secret, without speaking of it. Thus, misfortune will dissipate, and blessings will gather.

chunks.translated_text:
Virtue is the myriad of good deeds. Though the myriad practices bear myriad names, their essentials number nine: first, refraining from killing; second, refraining from licentiousness; third, refraining from falsehood; fourth, refraining from theft; fifth, refraining from perversity; sixth, refraining from wrath; seventh, refraining from envy; eighth, refraining from arrogance; ninth, refraining from stagnation. These are the Nine Virtues, possessed by those who attain the Dao.

The Nine Meritorious Deeds are these: first, releasing life and rescuing the dying; second, rewarding chastity and encouraging purity; third, offering loyalty and demonstrating trustworthiness; fourth, bestowing alms and eliminating greed; fifth, moderating wine and upholding integrity; sixth, reconciling disputes and admonishing strife; seventh, prohibiting villainy and halting jealousy; eighth, respecting and loving both high and low; ninth, alleviating sorrow and resolving distress. These are the Nine Meritorious Deeds, impartial and selfless.

Merit is cultivated outwardly, while virtue is established inwardly. With inner foundation and outer practice, the divine will surely descend upon you in secret. Those of exceptional talent and diligent practice may verify this in silence; transmit it only to those of like mind, and reveal it to no others. Observe the differences, and let your heart discern their significance. By this method, the efficacy of past and present may be known. Those lacking merit and practice will perceive it dimly, or their eyes may be deceived by malevolent spirits, seeing what seems but is not—proclaiming misfortune as fortune, or fortune as misfortune—contradicting the scriptures. In such cases, one should reflect on one’s transgressions and repent inwardly before observing again.

1. The first is the Lady of the Supreme Palace, the Hidden and Concealed Consort of the Primordial, surnamed Yanming, with the taboo name Taiyi Fatǎn, styled Xing Zhengfu. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a yellow brocade mantle and a vermilion-and-indigo flying skirt, her hair bound in a cloud-like topknot—later eight topknots are the same.

2. The second is the Lady of the Middle Prime Palace, the Womb-Protecting and Form-Transforming Consort, surnamed Kaiguan, with the taboo name Taiyi Sanlai Píng, styled Luozhu Ying. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a blue-green brocade mantle and a green-feathered flying skirt.

3. The third is the Holy Mother of the True Prime Palace, Mistress of the Six Concealments and Seven Hiding-Places, surnamed Mingmeng, with the taboo name Taiyi Lingyi, styled Chong Shuangzhao. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a blue-green brocade mantle and an embroidered-feather patterned skirt.

4. The fourth is the Lady of the Hidden Light Palace, the Concealing Radiance and Veiling Brilliance Consort of the Middle Prime, surnamed Kaoyao, with the taboo name Taiyi Qilie, styled Heng Danpan. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a purple brocade mantle and a yellow-flowered feathered skirt.

5. The fifth is the Great Maiden of the Net-Spirit Palace, the Body-Transforming and Brilliance-Altering Maiden of the Dipper’s Center, surnamed Xuanlu, with the taboo name Taiyi Yushu, styled Chou Qiulan. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a vermilion brocade mantle and a purple-and-indigo flying skirt.

6. The sixth is the Middle Maiden of the Bright Record Palace, the Concealing Traces and Dispersing Brilliance Maiden of the Dipper’s Center, surnamed Feilian, with the taboo name Taiyi Qijing, styled Baoding Ling. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a vermilion brocade mantle and a blue-green embroidered flying skirt.

7. The seventh is the Youngest Maiden of the Barrier Assembly Palace, the Multiform and Brilliance-Dividing Maiden of the Dipper’s Center, surnamed Wengchong, with the taboo name Taiyi Yumo, styled Tian Fan Shu. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a cinnabar brocade mantle and a blue-green-flowered feathered skirt.

8. The eighth is the Left Lady of the High Emperor’s Seat Palace, the Sun-and-Moon-Transforming and Water-and-Fire-Transforming Consort of the Dipper’s Center, surnamed Changming, with the taboo name Taiyi Shiqizhu, styled Luomaohua. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a purple brocade mantle and an embroidered-feather flying cinnabar skirt.

9. The ninth is the Right Lady of the Supreme Venerable Palace, the Metal-and-Stone and Mountains-and-Rivers-Transforming Consort of the Dipper’s Center, surnamed Konghuang, with the taboo name Taiyi Aixiu, styled Yun Yuxuan. Her true name is [omitted]. She wears a green brocade mantle and a kingfisher-feather patterned skirt.

The above are the Nine Imperial Lords and the Nine Hidden Consorts of the Dipper’s Central Palace, along with their Yin names. When invoking or reciting them, mention only their titles and names, without describing their attire, mantles, or hairstyles.

If you can master the Nine Yin [names] of the Imperial Lords, you will ascend at dawn to the heavens and be enfeoffed as a Perfected One of the Highest Clarity. Throughout your life, you will be spared the disasters of mourning and calamity. The spirits of the Great Yin will guard and attend you, and the myriad numinous beings will bow in reverence. You will divide your form and disperse your transformations, merging with Heaven and Earth.

These Nine Ladies of the Great Yin are the Yin officials and spirits of the Imperial Lords. If you practice the Dao, untie karmic knots, present talismans to the celestial registers, pacify the hun-soul, control the po-soul, transform and generate the body’s spirit and qi, and refine essence to seek longevity—yet remain ignorant of the names of the Imperial Consorts and fail to practice the Nine Yin to achieve union—you will never attain immortality.

One *cun* inward from the space between the eyebrows lies the Hall of Light, a perfect square of one *cun*, where the Nine Yin Consorts of the Imperial Lord constantly reside. Always on the even days of the month, during the hours of living qi, burn incense and enter a separate chamber. Sit or recline as you wish, close your eyes for a long while, and visualize the Imperial Lord seated in the Purple Chamber of the Supreme Ultimate. Then visualize the Five Spirits of Taiyi within the Six Harmonies, the Nine Stars of the Northern Dipper within your heart, and the Nine Yin Consorts within the Hall of Light. Next, visualize the Luminous Essence Lad of the Grand Tenuity standing before the Imperial Lord, the lad holding the Five Talismans in his left hand and the Five Registers in his right. Then visualize your own form standing behind the lad. Afterward, visualize the Nine Yin Consorts ascending from the Hall of Light into the Purple Chamber of the Supreme Ultimate, standing in a horizontal line behind you in order. Then visualize the Five Spirits of Taiyi ascending from the Six Harmonies into the Purple Chamber of the Supreme Ultimate, standing in a horizontal line behind the Nine Yin Consorts.

Once all is complete, the Imperial Lord and the host of spirits suddenly merge into one, transforming into a single being resembling a newborn infant, named the Eternal Lad, styled Transformation. In his left hand he holds the Nine Stars, on his head he wears the sun, and in his mouth he holds the moon. The lad illuminates your entire body with the light of the sun, moon, and Nine Stars, penetrating you inside and out. You will feel your body suffused with red, ablaze like fire, with no distinction between inner and outer—all radiant and luminous.

This is the myriad transformations of the Imperial Lord, Taiyi, and the Nine Yin in union. After a long while, conclude by knocking the teeth twenty-four times and swallowing saliva nine times. Then softly intone the incantation:

"Radiant spirit of the Grotto-Heaven,
revolving and illuminating the Purple Clarity,
Nine Mornings of the Dark Yin,
concealed and submerged in the unfathomable.
Ladies of the Dipper’s midst,
Three Maidens dispersing their forms..."

The divine consorts transform within, and the myriad things instantly take form. Lightning flashes and thunder crashes, clouds and mists flow like ringing bells. Nine transformations and ten evolutions give rise to cinnabar and bring forth verdant hues. The Nine Maidens of Taiyi unite in harmonious fusion, while the Lad of Impermanence roams freely, vanishing into the void and weaving through the obscure.

Adorned in brocade capes and resplendent sleeves, their skirts of purple feathers take flight. To their left, they bear concealed talismans; to their right, tiger-patterned sashes. They hold the Dipper in their mouths and wear fire upon their heads, grasping the banner of absolutes. Beside them, they command the Eight Winds, and from all four directions, they draw forth radiant clouds. Roaming the celestial net, they dissolve the Seven Origins, concealing mountains and rivers. They turn the Five Celestial Bodies, eclipsing the sun’s brilliance, and the constellations lose their true forms.

Dividing into a hundred shapes, their transformed bodies enter a thousand. In fire, they become fire; in forests, they become forests. In water, they become water; in mountains, they become mountains. What is sought arrives in an instant; what is summoned appears before one. In the blink of an eye, desires are fulfilled, and with a glance, all is attained. A thousand kinds and ten thousand things follow the heart’s command.

The Imperial Lord takes form, and the Supreme Jade Clarity of Tai Shang shares the same radiance. The Primordial Hero and the Four Scripts of White Origin endure with heaven and earth, preserving and nurturing my body. Whatever the mouth utters, transformations follow intent. Jade lads attend in service, jade maidens hold towels, divine consorts offer incense, and the Four Perfected share the same carriage. Every matter and thing conforms to my words.

*The Inner Mystery Scripture of the River Chart of Supreme Clarity* concludes.
